awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CyberTraining: CIU: Toward Distributed and Scalable Personalized Cyber-Training
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is addressing the challenge of providing distributed, scalable, and personalized training of cyberinfrastructures - systems that offer state-of-the-art cloud services for storing, sharing, and processing scientific data. Today, personalized training of these rapidly evolving, and hence relatively undocumented, systems requires trainer-supervised, hands-on use of these systems. These training sessions require trainees and trainers to be co-located and provide personalized training to a relatively small number of trainees. The project is developing new (a) domain-independent technologies in distributed collaboration and machine learning to reduce all three problems in a concerted manner, and (b) domain-dependent training material targeted at trainees in statistics, physical sciences, computer science, humanities, and medicine. It, thus, serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science; to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.

A key technical insight in this work is that a cyberinfrastructure should not only support data science, but also make use of data science. The project is exploring two related innovations based on this insight: (1) Collaboration technologies that log, visualize and share the work of remote and local trainees to allow trainers to determine the need for remote or face-to-face assistance.  (2) Machine-learning technologies that mine trainee and trainer interactions so that trainees can be automatically instructed on how to solve their problems based on similar problems that have been previously solved by trainers and other trainees. The project is leveraging existing technologies and training techniques developed for a widely used NSF-supported cyberinfrastructure, called CyVerse. This system is domain-independent, but so far, its training material has been targeted mainly at plant-science research.  The project is extending the command interpreters and GUIs provided by CyVerse. The extended user-interfaces allow (a) trainees to announce difficulties and request recommendations, and (b) trainers to be aware of the progress of remote and local trainees, and remotely intervene when necessary. The functionality behind the user-interfaces is implemented by CyVerse-independent servers based on a general model of cyberinfrastructures, which includes the concepts of sharing and visualization of protected files, creation and execution of parameterized commands composed in workflows, and shareable, persistent work spaces. The project is adapting the CyVerse training material to cover new research domains including Geoscience, Political Science, and Biomedical Engineering. This expanded training material is being used to evaluate the proposed training technologies through training sessions for (a) students in a Statistics, Computer Science, Political Science, and interdisciplinary course, (b) attendees at three conferences targeted at Geoscientists, women, and Hispanics and Native Americans, respectively, (c) subjects in controlled lab studies, and (d) members of research groups at multiple institutes. The proposed qualitative and quantitative evaluation data gathered from these sessions are being used to assess not only the proposed technologies and training material, but also CyVerse and cyberinfrastructures in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has addressed the challenge of providing distributed, scalable, and personalized hands-on training in the technologies that drive cloud cyberinfrastructures. Today such training requires trainers to be co-located with a relatively small number of trainees. The project has developed new (a) domain-independent technologies in visualization, distributed collaboration, and machine learning to reduce all three problems in a concerted manner, and (b) domain-dependent training material targeted at trainees in data science. It thus serves the national interest, as stated by NSF's mission: to promote the progress of science.

A key technical insight in this work is that a cyberinfrastructure should not only support data science, but also make use of data science. The project has developed two related innovations based on this insight: (1) Collaboration technologies that log, visualize, and share the work of remote and local trainees to allow trainers to determine the need for remote or face-to-face assistance. (2) Machine-learning technologies that mine trainee and trainer interactions so that trainees can be automatically instructed on how to solve their problems based on similar problems previously solved by trainers and other trainees.

At the heart of these innovations is a programming environment that is more sophisticated than anything we see today. Its architecture is shown in the accompanying figure.

 The environment provides integration and amplification of the capabilities of four classes of tools used today to develop programs. These include (from top to bottom in the figure) testing tools (e.g. junit), compilers (e.g. gcc), program development environment (e.g. shell), and discussion forums (e.g. Piazza). The boxes for these are colored orange, blue, purple, and green, respectively, in the figure. The environment is heterogeneous in that it supports multiple members of a tool class – for example, the Eclipse and Jupyter programming environments. It is a human-in-the-loop collaborative environment in that the help received by developers is generated and/or mediated by one or more helpers. It is scalable in that a single helper can monitor the activities of hundreds of developers, thereby supporting scalable help. The environment involves use of existing AI technology and development of new AI technology – thus it is an example of human-AI collaboration.

The accompanying figure also shows the event flow in the system. Plug-in modules trap events from existing integrated interactive tools so that the developer’s relevant activities can be monitored. These modules also inject events into the environment to allow in-place feedback, that is, feedback within the tool’s user interface.  These are then translated into a universal form to abstract away differences among different members of a class of tools. The translated events are processed to create feedback, which is communicated to the developer and/or trainer through appropriate visualizations.

This architecture is a first-cut blueprint for future technologies addressing our goals.

Below, we highlight some of the accomplishments based on this architecture.

Plugins For each of the eleven existing systems shown in the figure, we have used APIs to support event interception and injection.

Cloud-based Logging: The event interception code for these systems anonymously logs relevant information to the cloud. Our database has received logs of over ten thousand trainee assignments from more than a thousand different trainee computers.

Data set creation: Supervised machine learning algorithms require labeled data sets to make inferences. We have labeled about seven thousand Piazza posts made by students in thirteen UNC courses to automate responses to these posts. In addition, we have labeled four hundred assignment submissions in two Python data science coding assignments to automate feedback to them.

Prediction algorithms: We have developed and evaluated a variety of new supervised algorithms for predicting the labels of both the Piazza and Python data sets and compared their performance with GPT’s prediction ability.

Mediated Access to AI Systems: We have extended the user-interface of the popular Jupyter programming environment that makes it easy for trainees to ask existing AI systems (such as GPT) questions about their code and strips out all code from the responses of these systems to aid learning. Similarly, we have extended the popular Piazza discussion forum to allow instructors and AI algorithms to work together to respond to Piazza posts.

Dashboards:  We have implemented and extended three existing dashboards to help trainers visualize the actions of trainees and find those needing personalized assistance.

Online exercises: We have developed two new online lecture-less exercises to offer training in the creation of scientific workflows and writing data science code. We have used these exercises to train over two hundred trainees.

All products of this work - the architecture, plug-ins, cloud-based logging capabilities, labeled data sets, inference algorithms, mediated access to AI systems, dashboards, and online exercises – have persistence beyond the lifetime of this project and can be expected to form the bases for future scalable AI-based visualized cybertraining.
